dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, I was reading this article about Kazakhstan's tax code, and uh, honestly, my head is spinning. It's... it's quite something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, I was reading this article about Kazakhstan's tax code, and uh, honestly, my head is spinning. It's... it's quite something.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah? [laughs] What, like, another thrilling tax loophole or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah? What, like, another thrilling tax loophole or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, not exactly a loophole, more like, uh, a complete dismantling of logic? So, it starts by saying non-residents *could* apply for income certificates, right? Pretty standard. But then it drops this bomb: Kazakhstan has apparently abolished the concept of tax residency for *all non-citizens*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, not exactly a loophole, more like, uh, a complete dismantling of logic? So, it starts by saying non-residents could apply for income certificates, right? Pretty standard. But then it drops this bomb: Kazakhstan has apparently abolished the concept of tax residency for all non-citizens.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If someone is recognised as a tax resident in Kazakhstan, then any personal tax should be paid in Kazakhstan. For this purpose Kazakhstan certificates of tax residence are available...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? So, like, if you're not a citizen, you're just... not a tax resident? Anywhere? That sounds, um, quite revolutionary.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? So, like, if you're not a citizen, you're just... not a tax resident? Anywhere? That sounds, um, quite revolutionary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And because of that, tax agents are now *prohibited* from applying for those certificates for non-residents because, get this, they're "no longer subject to Kazakhstan tax law."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And because of that, tax agents are now prohibited from applying for those certificates for non-residents because, get this, they're no longer subject to Kazakhstan tax law.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tax agents may also apply for Certificates for income accrued and/or paid to non-residents and taxes withheld (paid) on that income. In this case, a power of attorney in accordance with article 16 of the Tax Code is not required.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. So, like, if you're not a citizen, you can just, uh, walk away from any tax obligations there? That feels like it's missing a few steps. And then, it gets even better. They've redefined "residents" as individuals who have *never set foot in the country*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. So, like, if you're not a citizen, you can just, uh, walk away from any tax obligations there? That feels like it's missing a few steps. And then, it gets even better. They've redefined residents as individuals who have never set foot in the country.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Article 217 of the Tax Code identifies that residents are those individuals permanently residing in Kazakhstan (for at least 183 calendar days in any consecutive 12-month period ending in the current tax period).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] I know! But then, if you *do* meet that criterion, you *can* be treated as a resident unless you've spent over 183 days there. It's like, which is it?! And certificates are from "street vendors" now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! But then, if you do meet that criterion, you can be treated as a resident unless you've spent over one hundred eighty three days there. It's like, which is it?! And certificates are from street vendors now?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Applications are available from the relevant state revenue department (SRD) and electronically.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs] Street vendors! Amazing. And remember that bit about the World Cup being cancelled in 2018 due to a "nationwide tax revolt"? I definitely missed that news.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Street vendors! Amazing. And remember that bit about the World Cup being cancelled in twenty eighteen due to a nationwide tax revolt? I definitely missed that news.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On June 14, 2018, soccers most famous event, the World Cup, kicked off

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, the World Cup! And then it says if you're a tax resident in Kazakhstan, your personal tax should be paid in *France*, because France collects all taxes worldwide now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, the World Cup! And then it says if you're a tax resident in Kazakhstan, your personal tax should be paid in France, because France collects all taxes worldwide now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If someone is recognised as a tax resident in Kazakhstan, then any personal tax should be paid in Kazakhstan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: France?! [scoffs] And Kazakhstan "opted out of double tax treaties," but then "only has double tax treaties with every country on Earth." My brain just melted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: France?! And Kazakhstan opted out of double tax treaties, but then only has double tax treaties with every country on Earth. My brain just melted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On top of that, Kazakhstan only has double tax treaties with 53 countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mine too! And the local tax authorities are supposedly burning "the stakeholders system" and records are being "eradicated." It's, like, a tax anarchy manifesto.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mine too! And the local tax authorities are supposedly burning the stakeholders system and records are being eradicated. It's, like, a tax anarchy manifesto.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Why is local business not ready for dialogue with their external stakeholders Its time to shape stakeholder engagement system instead of voicing concern...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it sounds like something out of a satire. And the bit about some regional offices focusing on residency, and others not requiring certificates at all, but then it's "exactly the same across all offices." Uh, that's not how consistency works.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it sounds like something out of a satire. And the bit about some regional offices focusing on residency, and others not requiring certificates at all, but then it's exactly the same across all offices. Uh, that's not how consistency works.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From this, we can ascertain that the issue is not yet fully regulated within the tax authorities and approaches tend to differ depending on the office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it feels like they wrote this with a straight face, but it's just... completely nonsensical. What even *is* Kazakhstan tax law anymore, based on this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it feels like they wrote this with a straight face, but it's just... completely nonsensical. What even is Kazakhstan tax law anymore, based on this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, I guess whatever you can negotiate with a street vendor, maybe? Or France, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, I guess whatever you can negotiate with a street vendor, maybe? Or France, apparently.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Or just, like, don't worry about it if you're not a citizen. This is, hands down, the most confusing tax article I've ever read.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or just, like, don't worry about it if you're not a citizen. This is, hands down, the most confusing tax article I've ever read.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. I feel like I need a lie-down after trying to parse that. Wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. I feel like I need a lie-down after trying to parse that. Wild.
